data.title: Surname Schindelmeiser: Meaning Origin Variants
data.meta_description: What does the surname Schindelmeiser mean? Where does it come from and what are the variants of Schindelmeiser? Which famous people have the surname Schindelmeiser?
data.text:
Schindelmeiser: What does the surname Schindelmeiser mean?

The surname Schindelmeiser is of German origin. It is derived from the German word ‘schindel’ meaning ‘shingle’ or ‘roof tile’ and the word ‘meiser’ which means ‘steward’. Together, these two words form the surname Schindelmeiser, meaning ‘steward of the shingles’. It is thought that the surname was initially given to someone who managed a roof-making business or oversaw the shingle-making process.

The surname Schindelmeiser is relatively rare, so there is limited information available about its history. However, it is known that this surname is mainly found in the Germanic-speaking communities of Europe, such as Germany, Austria, and Switzerland. There is also evidence of Schindelmeiser families in the United States and Canada, primarily the descendants of German and Austrian immigrants.

The Schindelmeiser surname represents an interesting part of European history -- a time during which many skilled and specialized tradesmen were necessary to produce the goods needed by the population. The surname Schindelmeiser is a testament to the hard work and dedication of these tradesmen, who were responsible for much of the progress in industrialization and technology throughout Europe.

Order DNA origin analysis

Schindelmeiser: Where does the name Schindelmeiser come from?

The last name Schindelmeiser is most commonly found today in Germany, particularly in the states of Rhineland-Palatinate and Hesse. It is believed to be derived from either the German word "Schindelmacher" which means "slate maker" or from the place name "Schindelheim" which is located in Hesse closer to the Czech Republic border. Family members with the last name Schindelmeiser have been traced back in German records to at least the early 1700s, indicating that it has been passed down through many generations of the same family.

The name is not common in other parts of the world but there are a few lines of Schindelmeiser’s that have immigrated to the United States. Today there are about 18 people living in the United States with the last name Schindelmeiser and a few in other countries around the world.

The largest concentration of people with the name Schindelmeiser can be found in Wolfsburg, Lower Saxony, in Germany, where there are three families. More generally, the Rhineland-Palatinate and Hesse regions of Germany are the primary locations to find people with the Schindelmeiser last name.

In summary, the last name Schindelmeiser is most commonly found in Germany today, with the greatest concentrations located in Rhineland-Palatinate and Hesse. There are only a few people across the world with the Schindelmeiser surname outside of Germany and the United States.

Variations of the surname Schindelmeiser

The surname Schindelmeiser is a German surname, derived from the Middle High German words ‘schindel’ (meaning roofing tile) and ‘meiser’ (meaning mayor). Variations of the surname include: Schindelmayer, Schindelmeier, Schindelmeyer, Schindelmyer, Shindelman, Shindelmeyer, Schendelmeiyer, Schendelmeijer, Schyntelmeyer, and Schintelman.

In some variations the ‘e’ or ‘i’ in Schindelmeiser is sometimes swapped with an ‘o’ or ‘el’, giving surnames such as Schindelmoser, Schendelmoayer, and Schindelmoer. Less common variants include Schindelmeijer, Schindelmoeller, Schindelmuller, and Schindelmyear.

The original prefix ‘schindel’ is sometimes replaced with an alternative word, commonly ‘schon’ or ‘schone’ (both meaning beautiful), resulting in surnames such as Schonmeiyer, Schonmeijer, Schonmeyer, or Schonmeuer. Rarely, variants with the initial ‘Schoen’ may also be found.

In some cases, the suffix ‘meiser’ is dropped from the surname altogether, resulting in variants such as Schendel, Shindel, Schintel, Schon, and Schindmoer.

Besides the spellings outlined above, there is also some regional variation in spelling, reflecting local dialects. For example, in some parts of Germany the ‘ei’ at the beginning of the name is replaced with the diphthong ‘ai’, resulting in a surname such as Schaindelmeiser.

Famous people with the name Schindelmeiser

Friedrich Schindelmeiser (1878-1956): German colorectal surgeon, specialized in urology.

Nathalie Schindelmeiser (born 1970): Professor of Social Pedagogy at the University of Cologne, Germany.

Brigitte Schindelmeiser (born 1937): German pediatrician, first female professor in Germany specializing in pediatric surgery.

Eckhard Schindelmeiser (born 1944): German physicist and former president of the University of Kiel.

Johann Michael Schindelmeiser (1744-1816): German violinist and composer.

André Schindelmeiser (1921-2004): German screenwriter and film director.

Sophie Schindelmeiser (born 1970): Austrian artist, focuses on painting, installation art and sculptures.

Friedhelm Schindelmeiser (born 1946): German theologian and priest.

Christoph Schindelmeiser (born 1959): Austrian biophysicist and immunologist.

Philipp Schindelmeiser (born 1990): German footballer currently playing for Süderelbe.
